texts.definition: A surface designed to support gameplay.
markups: Many games require that game elements are moved between places or that their spatial relation to each other are part of the game state. Yet others have many game components that need to be organized to make gameplay feasible. Designed boards, <style="CurrentLink">Game Boards</style>, can help with all these issues.

<style="CurrentLink">Game Boards</style> are the defining characteristic of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style>. Besides classical examples such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diplomacy">Diplomacy</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Monopoly">Monopoly</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pachisi">Pachisi</link></style>, there are many examples including <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/7%20Wonders">7 Wonders</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Advanced%20Squad%20Leader">Advanced Squad Leader</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Agricola">Agricola</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Car%20Wars">Car Wars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Concordia">Concordia</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dead%20of%20Winter:%20A%20Crossroads%20Game">Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Egizia">Egizia</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Forbidden%20Island">Forbidden Island</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/King%20of%20Tokyo">King of Tokyo</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Memoir%20'44">Memoir '44</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Twilight%20Struggle">Twilight Struggle</link></style>.
For a detailed discussion of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> and <style="CurrentLink">Game Boards</style>, see Parlett.

The design of <style="CurrentLink">Game Boards</style> consists of the actual design of the board and what game elements, e.g. <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="dice">Dice</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tokens">Tokens</link></style>, should be used in conjunction with them. Designing <style="CurrentLink">Game Boards</style> can mostly be treated as designing <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> although this becomes most clear when a game uses several different <style="CurrentLink">Game Boards</style> during one game instance. <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> can also be used, and are most likely used more often.

Examples of design elements that can be used to populate <style="CurrentLink">Game Boards</style> are numerous. <style="Link"><link="alarms">Alarms</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="controllers">Controllers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>,  <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="landmarks">Landmarks</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="pick-ups">Pick-Ups</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Resource%20Generators">Resource Generators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="self-service-kiosks">Self-Service Kiosks</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="spawn-points">Spawn Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="switches">Switches</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="warp-zones">Warp Zones</link></style> are all examples of specific items and things that can be placed on <style="CurrentLink">Game Boards</style>. In addition, <style="Link"><link="big-dumb-objects">Big Dumb Objects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style> can be used to provide information to players about the boards. <style="CurrentLink">Game Boards</style> can further be subdivided into various regions with specific characteristics through the use of the previously mentioned patterns as well as how various parts of them are interconnected. Examples of such regions include <style="Link"><link="arenas">Arenas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="backtracking-levels">Backtracking Levels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="choke-points">Choke Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="flanking-routes">Flanking Routes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="galleries">Galleries</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="safe-havens">Safe Havens</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="secret-areas">Secret Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sniper-locations">Sniper Locations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Strongholds">Strongholds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="transport-routes">Transport Routes</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="vehicle-sections">Vehicle Sections</link></style>. Many of these become <style="Link"><link="strategic-locations">Strategic Locations</link></style>.
If a <style="CurrentLink">Game Board</style> isn't a <style="Link"><link="score-tracks">Score Track</link></style> in itself it can be augmented with one.

<style="CurrentLink">Game Boards</style> are often <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Maps">Maps</link></style> and in that sense can depict <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. When they are used to keep track of how players move <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tokens">Tokens</link></style> from one place to another to win, they also work as <style="Link"><link="score-tracks">Score Tracks</link></style>. When they are used with <style="Link"><link="dice">Dice</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tokens">Tokens</link></style>, the latter becomes <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style> in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>.

When they are physical game components (as opposed to representations on a computer screen), <style="CurrentLink">Game Boards</style> work against <style="Link"><link="ubiquitous-gameplay">Ubiquitous Gameplay</link></style> since players need to be near them to use them.
